key_work.brief_description: The GoPro was designed as an action camera, making it as tough and durable as whatever adventure the shooter was partaking in. Originally invented for surf photography, they’re made to be attached to a body or moving object.

start.title: GoldenEye 007
start.brief_description: GoldenEye 007 inspired endless fun when it was released on the Nintendo 64 – just as long as you didn’t look at anyone’s screen or play as Odd Job. One of the first multi-player first-person-shooters for console, GoldenEye made everyone 007.

recommendations.quote: There's never been a better adaptation of film into a videogame than Golden Eye. For the first time, up to four players could shoot it out on one TV screen and take control of one of some of cinema's best heroes and villains. And yes, Odd Job is cheating.

end.title: Maze War
end.creator_credit: Steve Colley, Greg Thompson and Howard Palmer
end.brief_description: Without Maze War, there wouldn’t be any first-person shooter videogames like Quake or Doom. Developed by Steve Cooley for NASA, Maze War featured forward, backwards, left and right movements, as well as first-person perspective.

constellations_other.name: Capturing first-person POV

links.description: GoldenEye 007 is a descendent of Maze War (1973), a computer game developed by Steve Cooley for NASA which is considered one of the original first-person shooters.

end.title: Peeping Tom
end.creator_credit: Michael Powell and Michael Powell (Theatre) Ltd
end.brief_description: A withdrawn psychopath films young women as he impales them with the camera’s tripod, forcing them to watch their own death throes in a mirror mounted on the camera. Now considered a masterpiece, Michael Powell’s film foreshadowed the slasher genre.

constellations_other.name: Capturing first-person POV
constellations_other.description: A comparison of how videogames and feature films have used first person POV shots and sequences and how (for the latter) camera technology has impacted on this.

links.description: Before Strange Days, POV shots were slower and less dynamic because of the size and weight of 35mm cameras. But they were still effective and terrified audiences in Peeping Tom, one of the first films to show a killer’s POV.
